118784.name: Envoyer (Issue 75 - Jan 2003)
118784.description: A superhero sepical including a story, articles and a scenario with the superhero theme.

118785.name: Envoyer (Issue 76 - Feb 2003)
118785.description: This issue contains a private eye adventure "Eine Studie in Scharlachrot"

118786.name: Envoyer (Issue 77 - Mar 2003)
118786.description: This issue contains the DSA advneture "Goldener Schatten"

118787.name: Envoyer (Issue 78 - Apr 2003)
118787.description: This issue contains the first part of the "Abentuer Werkstatt" for the creation of new adventures.

118788.name: Par For The Course
118788.description:
Australian golfing game.

Rather familiar territory. Tee up, establish wind direction, line and distance and roll the dice to simulate a game of golf. Basically, you choose your wanted line of shot and the dice may adjust the shot randomly.

Contents:
Game Board
Direction and Distance Finder
Slide rule
Distance gained by shot, hook or slice deviation chart
Wind duration and effect chart
Score card sheets
Pencil
3 dice

Endorsed by Billy Dunk (whoever he might be).

118789.name: a+d+d+d
118789.description:
a+d+d+d (pronounced "add")

4x5 board, squares sequentially numbered 1-20
2 sets of pawns, 12 each
1 colored die
4 plain dice




Roll the dice. Add the value of the colored die plus all, some, or none of the plain dice to total an unoccupied number on the board. (Pass if unable.) Place a pawn on the numbered square to claim it. The game ends when all squares are occupied. Points are tallied for each line of three or more pawns; the highest score wins.

Devin Stewart is credited as the inventor; Kate Jones is credited with the solitaire games.

118790.name: Gravitas
118790.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Gravitas players push the game tiles across the playing area, trying to create lines or blocks of their color.

Gravitas includes three play variants.

118791.name: Singapur
118791.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Two town builders have competing projects that vie for the most beautiful skyline, with the winner being the one who can see more houses when his game plan is realized. Singapur invites you to dream big – but only the one who is wide awake during play can win.

118792.description:
Albert Wesker

Level 1 (2): When Albert attacks a character or explores, you get +20 gold for that turn.

Level 2 (9): STORY MODE: During your turn, choose a Player. That Player gets +1 explore and must explore at least once on their next turn.
118792.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Albert Wesker Foil Promo

118793.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Infected Albert Wesker Foil Promo

91773.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Alliance

118793.description:
This one was given at the release Event for Alliance Set.

Albert Wesker

When this infected is revealed all other reveled infected get +10 health and +10 damage during this turn.

118794.description:
Ada Wong was given at participants at the League Play June/July 2011

Ada Wong

Level 1 (4): When Ada explores, you can look at the top card of the mansion and move it to the top or the bottom of the mansion.

Level 2 (8): At the beginning of your turn, you can get +1 action and -1 buy.
118794.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Ada Wong Foil Promo

118795.name: Favor of Olympus
118795.description:
Favor of Olympus is a deck customization game similar to deck building games. The game differs from others in the genre in that where a player plays his cards is important, there is a larger level of player interaction and that a player can grow or shrink his deck's size easily. Players start with 12 card decks but have the flexibility to lower the deck size to 0 cards or raise it as high as 20 or more cards. Players try to obtain the most victory points to win.

Set in mythical Greece, each player takes the role of a city ruler that must try to appease Zeus and his siblings. Each player utilizes followers and recruited heroes, each which have special powers.

Each player starts with the same deck of cards. Players choose to play their cards to wage war, recruit allies, sacrifice, go on legendary quests, increase their worship and battle powerful heralds of the gods.

The design incorporates ideas from several games including Dominion, Twilight Struggle and 7 Wonders.

118796.description:
It was given at the League Play Dec 2011

Level 1 (3): During your turn, you can attach a card from your hand to Yoko. In that case, if another card was already attached to Yoko due to this effect, mova that card yo your hand.

Level 2 (4): When Yoko`s health would be reduced to 0 or less, you can reduce her maximum health by 20 then heal her to full health instead.
118796.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Yoko Susuki Promo

118797.description:
It was given at League Play Dec 2011

Alyssa Ashcroft

Level 1 (2): When Alyssa explores, if she is only using 1 weapon, you can pay 20 ammo. In that case, that weapon gets +10 damage during this turn.

Level 2 (5): During your turn, you can name a card type. In that case, reveal the top card of your inventory, if the revealed card was the named type, draw it and you get +1 explore during this turn.
118797.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Alyssa Ashcroft Promo

118798.description:
It was given at League Play Dec 2011

Cindy Lennox

Level 1 (1): When you gain a card with a "herb" it its name, you get +1 buy during this turn.

Level 2 (5): At the beginning of your turn, if Cindy is at full health, Cindy deals an additional 20 damage during this turn.
118798.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game: Cindy Lennox Promo

118799.name: Unknown Ponies: the Failure is Awesome RPG

rpg.17154: Unknown Ponies: the Failure is Awesome RPG

118799.description:
Author Blurb:
Ever since I posted about the My Little Pony RPG I ran on New Years' Day, there has been a demand for the rules I used to run the game. It has taken me longer than I expected, but I have finished the first draft and am now putting this out for the Internet Hivemind to digest.

Please read it and tell me what you think. Or, even better, playtest it! Try and break the system (probably won't be difficult). I wholeheartedly welcome all constructive criticism.

118800.name: Legenden aus Dunklen Zeiten
118800.description:
from the back of the book

The Dark Ages: The once mighty Empire of Bosparan and the venerable Diamond Sultanate are in steady decline. Decadence and decay have spread, ancient knowledge is lost and on the edge of civilization barbaric peoples beset the old empires. In the cities, the mighty spin their webs in their palaces leaving their subjects to their fate. It is a dark and gloomy time, where there is little hope. And yet it is also a time where heroes are born that become legends of this era.

In "The Hidden Spark" the heroes must go on a quest for an heir to a particular lineage. In "Inspectores", they will witness the construction of the largest aqueduct of Aventuria and must supervise the construction work. "Dark alleys, Floating roads" leads to the heroes to Cuslicum where they need to investigate a sinister cult before the background of a throne conflict. In "The Heritage of Aslaban" they decide who should succeed the mighty Koptha. In "Vitis Shinxiris" the adventurers must assist a soldier who must bring a marshal's baton into safety. "On the ancestral paths" ultimately leads the heroes to Bosparan of the Dark Ages. While they are at the service of a patrician, many centuries later another party of heroes must deal with the events and legacies of the past.

118801.name: Les Aventures de Carlos
118801.description:
Game based on Franch Televison Series.

The winner is the one that accomplishes its mission and becomes the first well, the one and only, true Carlos, a friend of five characters from the TV series.

In his turn player rolls dice, representing the five characters over Carlos. Then he draws a card that corresponds to each episode of the box set. The player ends his turn by moving his pawn one square Carlos towards a figurine character to recover. Simply position the same episode box to retrieve a figurine.

When a player has recovered its five characters, it must still go on the island of Carlos to win. Therefore, the other players are in league against him to prevent him reaching the first. Each draw of Carlos, they will try to move it away from the island by sending boxes of remote episode.

118802.name: Envoyer (Issue 79 - May 2003)
118802.description: This issue contains an universal adventure taken from the free RPG YARG "Die Feste Jarjar"

118803.name: Rhand: Morningstar Missions
118803.description:
Back cover text:

A Complete Fantasy Role-Playing Game on the World of Rhand

Rhand is a fallen world, a world at war. A shattered humanity retreats each year before a wave of ice. Driven by hunger, the cultures of Rhand fight among themselves for the planet's dwindling resources, slowly reverting to complete barbarism. The faceless, inhuman Spectrals stalk through the ruins, existing only to destroy humanity.

In this chaos the only real stability lies in the city-states, small nations struggling to survive in a land of ice, war, and hatred. Beleaguered and isolated, the city-states and indeed all of Rhand have only one hope for the future: The ORCA.

An elite group of heroes and healers, the ORCA is the last chance for life and civilization in a world gone mad. Join the ORCA and enter the eternal battle for the fate of Rhand as you:

• Encounter the wily Jineta, master horsemen and rulers of the plains.
• Deal with the Clochardi, subtle and powerful humans who wrest life out of the icelands.
• Aid the reclusive Vid in their battle to save the vanishing forests they have made their homes.
• Combat the Vissers, warped, malevolent creatures that were once human.
• Pursue the twisted people who call themselves Blades, madmen who have betrayed their race for greed, power, and hatred.
• Battle the jet-black, unthinking Spectrals, the enemies of all life on Rhand.

And Rhand: Morningstar Missions gives you more than alien cultures, fascinating opponents and the glory of the ORCA's struggle to save a world; it gives you a revolution in game design. The unique rules system puts you on the battlefield:

• In the chaos of combat you must stab, slash, duck, and parry.
• Aim your blows where you wish — the limbs, the head, or even the heart.
• Batter down your opponent's shield to create an opening for an ally.
• Drag an enemy from horseback and continue the fight with or without weapons.
• Feel the tension of the bowstring on your fingertips.
• Wield the forces of magic — the powers of the elements and a full range of mental abilities.
• Master any skills you wish by study or field experience.

118804.name: Symbol
118804.description:
The object of the game is to Scribe to the other players guess a word, phrase or title with 40 symbols available.

One player as The Scribe gives to guess a word, phrase or title with 40 symbols available to other players.
All other players the decoders, observes the task for 1 minute and can make as many proposals as they want.

When a word, phrase, or title is found, the Scribe and the smart decoder both score 1 point. The winner is the one with the most points at the end of the game or he who first reached the number of points set at the start.

118805.name: Envoyer (Issue 80 - Jun 2003)
118805.description: This issue contains an adventure for DSA "Efferds Korn"

118806.name: Envoyer (Issue 81 - Jul 2003)
118806.description: This issue contains the 2nd part of the DSA adventure "Efferds Korn"

118807.name: Envoyer (Issue 82 - Aug 2003)
118807.description: This issue contains the GURPS adventure "Kerzeninsel" which was the winner of the adventure contest.

118808.name: J-League Soccer V-Shoot
118808.description:
User Summary

J-League Soccer V-Shoot is a head to head soccer game from Namco released in Japan. Play standard soccer rules and score the most goals to win the game.

118809.name: Jumping Groove
118809.description:
User Summary

Jumping Groove is a dancing rythm game released in Japan. Jump to the beat and hit the pads in time to score points.

118810.name: Kaitei Takara Sagashi
118810.description:
Kaitei Takara Sagashi is a 1980 arcade game that was developed by K'K Tokki as a prototype and later sold to Namco, where it was completely rewritten.

A boat lowers the player towards the bottom of the screen. Try to avoid the fish or push left or right to fire a harpoon at them. When at the bottom, if you walk over one of treasure caches, you will be lowered into it. Then you will be raised back to the ship (again, avoid the fish).

Source: Wikipedia, "Kaitei Takara Sagashi", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118811.name: Kart Duel
118811.description:
User Summary

Kart Duel is a kart racing game. Guide your go kart around the track and try to beat opponents and time to continue playing.

118812.name: Knockdown 2001
118812.description:
User Summary

Knockdown 2001 (KO 2001) is a boxing game from Namco. Hit an actual body bag to score points based on your strength of punch.

118813.name: Kosodate Quiz: My Angel
118813.description:
User Summary

Kosodate Quiz My Angel is a trivia game from Namco released in Japan. Answer questions to get to more rounds.

118814.name: Kosodate Quiz: My Angel 2
118814.description:
User Summary

Kosodate Quiz My Angel 2 is part of a trivia game series from Namco released in Japan. Answer questions to get to more rounds.

118815.name: Kosodate Quiz: My Angel 3
118815.description:
User Summary

Kosodate Quiz My Angel 3 is part of a trivia game series from Namco released in Japan. Answer questions to get to more rounds.

118816.name: Kyuukai Douchuuki
118816.description:
Kyūkai Dōchūki (球界道中記 lit. Baseball World Traveler's Journal?) is a baseball arcade game that was released by Namco in 1990 exclusively in Japan. It is a spin-off of Shadow Land (known as Yōkai Dōchūki in Japan).

Source: Wikipedia, "Kyūkai Dōchūki", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118817.name: Mach Breakers
118817.description:
User Summary

Mach Breakers is a track and field game from Namco. Compete in events and try to get scores to earn medals and continue on.

118818.name: Mario Kart Arcade GP 2
118818.description:
User Summary

Mario Kart Arcade GP 2 is a sequel to the 2005 racing game. Play Mario and other characters in a racing game against time.

118819.name: Bull Run to Gettysburg
118819.description:
American Civil War Rules and Campaigns
By David Bickley - 160 pages

Miniature wargame for figures at 25 - 28 mm scale.

Four infantry (4) figures make up a unit. 3-6 units make up a regiment. 4-6 regiments make up a brigade. Two (2) brigades make up a army. Some difference for cavallery, artillery and snipers/sharpshooters.

Troop types comprises infantry, cavallery, artillery and snipers/sharpshooters.

You go/he go - turns. Move/charge, shoot, replenish. D6 dices.
Every unit uses one dice for shooting and one dice for each unit in base contact when close combat is utilized.

There is also a couple of optional rules - Orders, Generals etc.

118820.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune
118820.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune is a racing game from Namco. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118821.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 2
118821.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 2 is a racing game in the popular Namco racing series. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118822.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3
118822.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3 is a GT racing game in the popular Namco racing series. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118823.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3DX
118823.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3 is a GT racing game in the popular Namco racing series. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118824.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3DX+
118824.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 3DX+ is a GT racing game in the popular Namco racing series. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118825.name: Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 4
118825.description:
User Summary

Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune 4 is a GT racing game in the popular Namco racing series. Race in different cars on various tracks. Try to beat the other racers to advance.

118826.name: Mazan: Flash Of The Blade
118826.description:
User Summary

Mazan: Flash Of The Blade is an intense action hack and slash from Namco. Features a massive cabinet and screen with a unique standing interface.

118827.name: Metal Hawk
118827.description:
Metal Hawk (メタルホーク) is a multi-directional shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1988 only in Japan. It runs on Namco System 2 hardware.

Source: Wikipedia, "Metal Hawk", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118829.name: Motocross Go!
118829.description:
User Summary

Motocross Go! is a sit down motorcycle racing game. Ride, jump and turn your way to victory. Beat other racers to continue.

118830.name: Navarone
118830.description:
Navarone is a fixed shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1980.

Source: Wikipedia, "Navarone (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118831.name: Immortal Grand Prix
118831.description:
Namco Bandai Games released IGPX: Immortal Grand Prix is only for Sony PlayStation 2.

Game Features:
-Play as Team Satomi in the IGPX to take the IG-1 League Championship.
-Over 10 different teams which means over 30 enemies.
-Customize with over 100 machine parts to make your mech the best!
-Several different courses combine with tons of variations make over 70 different track styles.
-Modes include Grand Prix Mode, Grand Prix Battles, Simulation Battles and the famed IGPX festival, which includes a 3 vs 3 Dream Match and
Battle Royales.
-2-player mode allows for two different people to race against each other.

There will be several teams not featured in the TV series that are in this game. Here is a partial list of those teams: Team Violence Bot, Team Whirlwind, Team Speed Star, Team Rolling Rock, Team Baby Face, Team Silver Crater, and Team Blue Rose.

Source: The Game Website.

118832.name: Nebulas Ray
118832.description:
Nebulas Ray is a vertical scrolling shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1994. It has many 3-D elements and very detailed graphics.

Source: Wikipedia, "Nebulas Ray", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118833.name: Nettou! Gekitou! Quiztou!!
118833.description:
Nettō! Gekitō! Quiz-tō!! (熱闘! 激闘! クイズ島!!) is a quiz arcade game that was released by Namco in 1993 only in Japan.
The game's name translates from Japanese as "Hot Fighting! Fierce Fighting! Quiz Island!!"

Source: Wikipedia, "Nettou! Gekitou! Quiztou!!", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118834.name: The Outfoxies
118834.description:
The Outfoxies (アウトフォクシーズ) is a 1994 arcade game by Namco that depicted several professional hitmen secretly set against each other by a held-in-common client "Mr. Acme". Acme and his wife had hired each of them to assassinate a wealthy art collector, then arranged for them to kill each other to ultimately avoid having to pay their fee.

The game is like a cross between shoot 'em up and a typical fighting game. It featured stages that zoom in and out depending on how close the two combatants are much like Art of Fighting and Samurai Shodown, but on a much larger scale given the immense size of some of the levels.

Source: Wikipedia, "Outfoxies", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118835.name: Panic Park
118835.description:
The game has 25 mini-games, 5 of which are solely the final stage in Solo Play, but can be any stage in VS Play. Rocket Panic is levels 1, 6, and 11, Electric Panic, levels 2, 7, and 12, Hammer Panic, 3, 8, and 13, Space Panic, 4, 9, and 14, and Jumping Panic, levels 5, 10, and 15. In addition, the game has a Panic King mode for one player only. In it, the player can set a high score, by attempting to beat the old record of the players who previously played the mode. In January and July, the Panic King stage is Shark Panic, in February and August, it is Buffalo Panic, in March and September, Missile Panic, in April and October, Jumping Panic, in May and November, Mole Panic, and in June and December, Fire Panic.

Source: Wikipedia, "Panic Park", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118836.name: Pistol Daimyo no Bōken
118836.description:
Pistol Daimyo no Bōken (ピストル大名の冒険 lit. "The Adventure of the Pistol Feudal Lord"?) is a side-scrolling shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1990 only in Japan. It runs on Namco System 1 hardware. It is a spin-off of Bravoman, as the titular character appeared in that game as a boss-type enemy. This game was never released in the United States, due to its slightly questionable content.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pistol Daimyo no Bōken", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118837.name: Pocket Racer
118837.description:
User Summary

Pocket Racer is a very cute fantasy take on a modern racing game. Race against opponents to continue play.

118838.name: Poitto
118838.description:
User Summary

Poitto is a head to head block dropping with gameplay similar to tetris.

118839.name: J-League Prime Goal EX
118839.description:
User Summary

J-League Prime Goal EX is a soccer game from Namco. Play by standard soccer rules using Japanese leagues.

118840.name: Prop Cycle
118840.description:
User Summary

Prop Cycle is a flight simulator game where you pedal a flying bicycle. Pop hot air balloons for points.

118841.name: Puzzle Club
118841.description:
Puzzle Club is the title of an unreleased prototype of an arcade game, developed by Namco in 1990.

Source: Wikipedia, "Puzzle Club", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118843.name: Quest For Fame
118843.description:
Quest for Fame is a music video game developed by Virtual Music and distributed by IBM. They were eventually acquired by Namco (who then made the arcade version in 1999) to create karaoke machines.
In 2001, they resurfaced with a web-based subscription product named Music Playground, allowing the user to purchase the instrument tracks for already-owned audio CDs and play along with them. The service failed to attract a sufficient number of users and was finally shut down in August 2003.

Source: Wikipedia, "Quest For Fame", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118844.name: Quick & Crash
118844.description:
User Summary

Quick & Crash is a light gun shooter from Namco. Draw the gun from the holster and fire as fast as you can to outdraw your opponents.

118845.name: Race On
118845.description:
Race On is an expansion pack to RACE 07 developed by SimBin and adds the 2008 World Touring Car Championship season, the International Formula Master series and some American Muscle Cars in both road and race-tuned versions to RACE 07. It was released internationally on October 16, 2009. It is available as a stand-alone game including Race 07 as well as its previous expansion pack STCC - The Game which was only release as a boxed copy in Scandinavia) and as an add-on pack to those who already have Race 07 and/or STCC - The Game.

Source: Wikipedia, "Race On", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118846.name: Rapid River
118846.description:
User Summary

Rapid River is a white water rafting game where you sit in a boat like structure and paddle down the river.

118847.name: Rave Racer
118847.description:
Rave Racer is a racing game created by Namco. It was released on July 16, 1995 for the Namco System 22 arcade platform. It is the third arcade title in the Ridge Racer series.

Source: Wikipedia, "Rave Racer", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118848.name: Rockin BowlORama
118848.description:
User Summary

Rockin BowlORama is a retro bowling game. Features an old school cabintet with a roller ball and good graphics.

Follows standard bowling rules and scoring.

118849.name: Rolling Extreme
118849.description:
User Summary

Rolling Extreme is a single player sit down Luge game. Race your sled down the track at optimum speeds for turning and straightaways.

118850.name: Samurai Surfin'
118850.description:
User Summary

Samurai Surfin' is an action game from Namco. Stand on the real surfboard and ride the virtual waves.

118852.name: SimDrive
118852.description:
User Summary

SimDrive is a driving game from Namco where you actually sit in a Mazda Miata with three screens.

118853.name: Star Sweep
118853.description:
User Summary

Star Sweep is a cutsy block and ball drop game where you fight head to head against your opponent. Make the connections before they do to survive.

118854.name: Star Trigon
118854.description:
Star Trigon is a series of video games developed by Namco. Star Trigon puts the player in the role of a spaceperson spinning around a planet, having to rescue the stranded aliens in time before his air supply runs out. Games in this series have been released for iPod, Windows, and iPhone in addition to the arcade versions.

Source: Wikipedia, "Star Trigon", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118855.name: Steel Gunner
118855.description:
Steel Gunner (スティールガンナー) is an arcade game that was released by Namco in 1990.

Garcia and Cliff are super cops in the Neo Arc (a play on Newark) police force. The professor and his assistant have been kidnapped and you must shoot your way through four missions to the final confrontation with the mysterious enemy superweapon!

Source: Wikipedia, "Steel Gunner", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118856.name: Steel Gunner 2
118856.description:
Steel Gunner 2 (スティールガンナー2) is an arcade game that was released by Namco in 1991. As the name suggests, it is the sequel to Steel Gunner, which was released in the previous year.
As in the earlier game, the players shoot at cyborgs while rescuing humans.

Source: Wikipedia, "Steel Gunner 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118857.name: Demon Chaos

videogamehonor.30289: 2006 D.I.C.E. Best Console Game of the Year Winner

118857.description:
Demon Chaos, known in Japan as Ikusagami (戦神, lit. God of War), is in vein of the well known Dynasty Warriors series. It is set in feudal Japan in the 16th century and revolves around a priestess who has been given eternal youth until she exterminates all the demons. She has been given charge of a mystical beast from the gods, Inugami, which is controlled by the player. The unique aspect of the game is that up to 65,535 enemies can be on-screen at once.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ikusagami", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary:

Gameplay is basically the hack and slash controls from Dynasty Warriors. While you fight as an individual using basic thrust and parry controls, you also have an allied army to assist in fighting hordes of enemies. You can set up health areas to support your army and fighting the monsters as they attack.

118858.name: Super Sky Kid
118858.description:
User Summary

In Super Sky Kid, you and your teammate fly planes shooting enemies. Collect powerups and bombs to drop on targets and bosses.

118859.name: Super World Court
118859.description:
Super World Court (スーパーワールドコート) is a tennis arcade game that was released by Namco in 1992 only in Japan. As the name suggests, it is the sequel to World Court, which was released 4 years earlier.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Court", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118860.name: Super World Stadium
118860.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118861.name: World Stadium '89
118861.description:
World Stadium '89 (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118862.name: World Stadium '90
118862.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118864.name: Super World Stadium '92
118864.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118865.name: Super World Stadium '93
118865.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118866.name: Super World Stadium '95
118866.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118867.description:

World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

118873.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

118874.name: IndyCar Series
118874.description:
IndyCar Series is a racing simulator developed by Codemasters. It is the fifteenth game of the Official IndyCar Series games series.

The game is based the 2002 IndyCar Series season in the series. A sequel to the game, IndyCar Series 2005 was released on June 24, 2004 for PlayStation 2 and Xbox based the 2003 IndyCar Series season.

Source: Wikipedia, "IndyCar Series (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118875.name: Suzuka 8 Hours 2
118875.description:
User Summary

Suzuka 8 Hours 2 is the sequel to the popular motorcycle racing game. Race as fast as you can to beat time and your opponents.

118876.name: Capt'n Sharky: Volle Fahrt voraus!
118876.description:
From the back of the box:

Full speed ahead! Sepio, the sea-monster wants to be the first to reach the light house. In order to prevent this, Capt'n Sharky and his crew try to sail around the dangerous obstacles to win the race.

An exciting race game where the players have to use their capacity for remembering in order to move the ship.

There are 18 obstacle cards with three symbols on each card which are placed face down in a circle with a gemstone on top. There are also 14 sea cards which each have one symbol. After 30 seconds of studying them, they are also turned face down. On your turn you turn up an obstacle card and then try to turn up a sea card which matches one of the symbols on the card. If you succeed, you collect the gemstone and move your ship forward between the next two cards. You can try it two more times, but the second time you must turn up two sea cards that match two symbols and the last time, 3 sea cards that match three symbols. Anytime you fail, the sea monster moves forward one obstacle card. Also, if you failed after collecting one or two gemstones, those gemstones are then placed on the last cards. The player with the most gemstones wins unless everyone loses. All players will lose if everyone takes on too much risk and the sea-monster passes the last obstacle card first.

Game-play thus incorporates both memory, press your luck and a bit of cooperation.

118877.name: Tank Battalion
118877.description:
Tank Battalion is a multi-directional shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1980. It was later ported to the Japanese Famicom (with a corresponding Vs. System game) and Game Boy, but for unknown reasons was retitled Battle City. This game was also ported to the MSX 8-bit computers with its original name.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tank Battalion", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118878.name: Tenkomori Shooting
118878.description:
User Summary

Tenkomori Shooting is a shoot'em up game borrowing graphics from other Namco classics.

118879.name: Thunder Ceptor
118879.description:
User Summary

Thunder Ceptor is a 3-d shooter from Namco. Shoot enemies and targets.

118880.name: Initial D: Arcade Stage 4
118880.description:
Initial D Arcade Stage 4 is the sequel to Initial D Arcade Stage Ver.3. This version has been heavily updated compared to its predecessors. The game underwent location testing from October 21, 2006 to October 30, 2006 in game centers in Tokyo, Osaka, and Aomori, Japan, and was released on February 21, 2007. The international version was released in July 2007 which is named Initial D 4.

Unlike the older games in this series, which were revisions of the original title, Initial D Arcade Stage 4 has a completely new physics engine written by Sega Rosso for the Sega Lindbergh arcade system. This new system allows cars to actually slide, or drift, across the track when turning corners; this is a feature not present in the older games. Initial D Arcade Stage 4 features animated cel-shaded characters interacting with each other, while the cars and environment use updated, high-definition graphics. The cabinet has a 32-inch 16:9 LCD screen supporting WXGA resolution (1366 x 768). The gear shift has been relocated to a lower more realistic location. The Japanese version of the game supports connection to Sega's All.Net online play network, allowing players from different arcades to play against each other.

The player cards for saving gameplay data have been changed to IC cards like other Lindbergh games such as Virtua Fighter 5, and Power Smash 3. The player can store data such as their vehicles, modifications to vehicles, avatar customizations and time attack times. Additionally, unlike the past three versions of the game, in which the player is limited to one car per card, the player can now store data for up to three different cars. Additionally, the IC Card can be used for 150 plays, as opposed to cards for past versions which can only be used for 50 plays. Players will not be able to transfer data from versions 1 through 3 due to the changes in both the player card and the card slot. The modification system has been updated as well, as car upgrades are no longer automatic, allowing players to choose which parts to upgrade and how they spend their reward points.

Source: Wikipedia, "Initial D Arcade Stage 4", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118881.name: Thunder Ceptor II
118881.description:
User Summary

Thunder Ceptor II is a sequel to Thunder Ceptor released the same year in Japan. Shoot enemies in this 3d shoot'em up.

118882.description:
Title Chase Basketball is a fast-paced game nominally about professional basketball. The game focuses on team building, getting into the playoffs and winning it all. Title Chase Basketball should not be confused with a simulation. It is a game meant to pit players against each other and as such can be completed from the start of the season to game seven of the finals in about an hour.

The first half of the game is a card-driven game where you build up your team by improving positions, winning key games and gain ground in the standings. You will need to decide what teams surge ahead and which ones will fall by the wayside. Do you build a team of all-stars quickly and have a giant bulls-eye placed on their back for the other players to shoot at. Do you turn your team of journeymen into a solid-all around squad. Or maybe you want those one or two superstars that can guarantee you a deep run into the playoffs. The way that you build your team is up to you.

At the end of the regular season, the game switches to a full-on dice game using the teams you created during the regular season. Teams match up in best of 7 series where your dice are the ones you labored to improve earlier. As your dice are expended in each series, the games get closer and closer and often it comes down to one final toss of the die.

Although the game does not use hard and fast statistics and has no built in way to produce them, I find that it really scratches that sports itch that I used to spend hours on back in the day with Statis-Pro Basketball. With Title Chase Basketball Carla & I can play it together even though she has only a passing knowledge of the sport. The game is meant to be played by players of all levels of sporting knowledge and still be fun. You don’t have to understand the triangle offense or why you take out your 44% free-throw shooter when you have the ball with 30 seconds left and are up by 3.
118882.name: Title Chase: Basketball

118883.name: Tinkle Pit
118883.description:
Tinkle Pit (ティンクルピット) is an arcade game that was released by Namco in 1993 only in Japan.

In Tinkle Pit, an evil wizard spawns monsters in a tiny village. The nameless protagonist of Tinkle Pit chooses to go on a world-saving quest to defeat the wizard and his minions. He is accompanied by an oversized, anthropomorphic sleigh bell as his weapon. The game's storyline is written in Japanese whilst the game itself employs mostly English text.
The game is divided into eight worlds. The first world has four rounds, and every other world has six rounds.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tinkle Pit", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118884.name: Tokyo Wars
118884.description:
This game allows one to eight players to control separate tanks (either as teammates or as opponents).[4] The player(s) can play either in the heart of downtown Tokyo or at the city's bayside dock.[4] However, the players have twenty seconds to make all the decisions before the game automatically locks them in. The tanks are identical except in color; green[4] (representing the Green Godzillas) and white[4] (representing the White Mammoth). The storyline provided by the game's promotional poster states that the game takes place in the 1990s.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tokyo Wars", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118885.name: Made Man
118885.description:
Made Man is set in the New York underworld of organized crime in the Mafia. The storyline is written by crime author David Fisher with collaboration from former mafioso Salvatore "Bill" Bonanno.

The player assumes the role of Joey Verola, a former soldier, as he is indoctrinated into the world of American organized crime and must relive his life - every moment, every kill - as he rises through the ranks to become a made man. The storyline spans three decades of his life, from the horror of Vietnam to the urban jungle of Brooklyn.

Joey is forced into the world of crime when he saves a don's right hand man in Vietnam. The game's missions are a series of flashbacks: as Joey is being driven to the don's place to be made he reveals to his nephew how he rose through the ranks.

The title was originally under development at Acclaim Entertainment's Manchester studio under the name of Interview with a Made Man. When Acclaim collapsed, employees from its studio reformed as SilverBack Studios, and backed by Fund4Games, continued to work on the game. The title was shortened to Made Man and a planned Xbox conversion was dropped.

Source: Wikipedia, "Made Man (computer game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118886.name: The Last Bounty Hunter
118886.description:
Promotional Poster

As a Bounty Hunter, you will be equipped with a six-shooter and sometimes a shotgun. Careful -- one of the gunfighters that protects the four outlaws is a world record holder in fast draw competation in real life. He is Wes Flowers, renowned world champion.

The pursuit of each outlaw will take you through different shootout scenarios and challenges. Plus, the order in which you stalk each outlaw will change the play action responses and difficultly level, making for a different game each time you play.

The Last Bounty Hunter is American Laser Games largest production and live-action cast to date. It is the first live-action game that automatically adjusts the difficulty level to the players' shooting skills.

The Last Bounty Hunter was filmed in an Old Tucson setting. The same locations as some of the greatest movies such as Tombstone, Geronimo, Rio Bravo, Gunsmoke, Lightning Jack and Posse. All with the assistance of The Old Tucson Studios.

118887.name: Truck Kyuukyoku
118887.description:
User Summary

Truck Kyuukyoku is a big rig truck driving simulator released in Japan.

118888.name: Turret Tower
118888.description:
User Summary

Turret Tower is a flight fighter pilot simulator with a very interestingly designed cabinet.

118889.name: Vs. Battle City
118889.description:
User Summary

Vs. Battle City is a maze action game where you drive your tank around and shoot objects and tanks.

118890.name: Ikki Tousen: Shining Dragon
118890.description:
This game is based on the anime Ikki Tousen (一騎当千 Ikkitōsen, lit. "Strength of a Thousand"), known in North America as Battle Vixens, also a manga series written and illustrated by Yuji Shiozaki, based on the classic Chinese novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms. The series revolves around an all-out turf war in the Kanto region of Japan where fighters known as Tōshi (闘士), meaning "fighting soldier," from seven schools battle for supremacy. The story centers on Hakufu Sonsaku, a fighter who transfers to Nanyo Academy, one of the seven schools involved in the turf war.

A video game of the series, Ikki Tousen: Shining Dragon (一騎当千 Shining Dragon Ikkitōsen Shainingu Doragon), was developed by Idea Factory and released for the PlayStation 2 in Japan on July 26, 2007 by Marvelous Entertainment. The game has an original storyline with Hakufu, Ryomou, and Kanu as the main playable characters. The game introduces a new character named Chousen, the Japanese counterpart of Diao Chan. Along with Hakufu, Ryomou, and Kanu, Gentoku Ryubi, Ukitsu, Ekitoku Chouhi, Shiryu Cho-n, Housen Ryofu, and Myosai Kakouen also appear as playable characters, with Koukin Shuyu appearing as an extra character in Hakufu and Ryomou's story arcs respectively.

Source: Wikipedia, "Battle Vixens", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118891.name: Warp & Warp
118891.description:
Warp & Warp (ワープ&ワープ?) is a multi-directional shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1981. The game was later ported to the MSX, and a sequel titled Warpman (ワープマン?) was released for the Famicom in 1985 with added features and improved graphics. The game was released in the United States by jukebox manufacturer Rock-Ola as Warp Warp.

Source: Wikipedia, "Warp & Warp", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118892.name: Winning Run
118892.description:
Winning Run is a video game, released by Namco in 1988. It was the first game to use the Namco System 21 hardware. The music was composed by Hiroyuki Kawada. It was housed in a movable (silver, orange) cabinet. In traditional NAMCO racer genre of the time it the player had a choice of game modes to play: Easy Drive (Automatic Transmission and slower game play) Technical Drive (Manual Transmission and faster game play) The game also featured a Dunlop "style" tire bridge over the track but instead said "NAMCO" on it. The music had similarities to Namco's Final Lap using the short jingles when the race started.

Source: Wikipedia, "Winning Run", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118894.name: Winning Run '91
118894.description:
User Summary

Winning Run '91 is another sequel in the popular Japanese racing game. Race against computer opponents to try to win races and continue.

118895.name: Winning Run Suzuka Grand Prix
118895.description:
User Summary

Winning Run Suzuka Grand Prix is another sequel in the popular Japanese racing game. Race against computer opponents to try to win races and continue.

118896.name: Ikki Tousen: Eloquent Fist
118896.description:
This game is based on the anime Ikki Tousen (一騎当千 Ikkitōsen, lit. "Strength of a Thousand"), known in North America as Battle Vixens, also a manga series written and illustrated by Yuji Shiozaki, based on the classic Chinese novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms. The series revolves around an all-out turf war in the Kanto region of Japan where fighters known as Tōshi (闘士), meaning "fighting soldier," from seven schools battle for supremacy. The story centers on Hakufu Sonsaku, a fighter who transfers to Nanyo Academy, one of the seven schools involved in the turf war.

This second video game in the series is entitled Ikki Tousen: Eloquent Fist (一騎当千 Eloquent Fist Ikkitōsen Erokuento Fisuto) and was developed by Tamsoft for the PlayStation Portable and released on October 2, 2008 by Marvelous Entertainment. The game is a hybrid between fighting and adventure, and it features 15 Ikki Tousen heroines and a new character named Kanpei, the Japanese counterpart of Guan Ping and the protagonist of the game. New characters include Motoku Sousou (Dragon Potent Unlocked), Teni, Koumei Shokatsuryo, Gentoku Ryubi, Genpou Saji, and Shishi Ouin, along with EX-Hakufu (Dragon Potent Unlock) and EX-Ryubi (Shining Dragon). Eloquent Fist omits the presence of Ukitsu, and new finishing maneuvers and altered movesets have either been buffed, or have been nerfed.

Source: Wikipedia, "Battle Vixens", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118897.name: World Court
118897.description:
User Summary

World Court is a late 80's Tennis game from Namco. Follows standard Tennis scoring and play.

118898.name: World Kicks
118898.description:
User Summary

World Kicks is a soccer game from Namco. Has good graphics with multiple panning camera angles. Follows standard soccer game play and scoring rules.

118899.name: Ikki Tousen: Xross Impact
118899.description:
This video game is based on the manga series Ikki Tousen (一騎当千 Ikkitōsen, lit. "Strength of a Thousand"), known in North America as Battle Vixens, written and illustrated by Yuji Shiozaki and based on the classic Chinese novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms. The manga series revolves around an all-out turf war in the Kanto region of Japan where fighters known as Tōshi (闘士), meaning "fighting soldier," from seven schools battle for supremacy. The story centers on Hakufu Sonsaku, a fighter who transfers to Nanyo Academy, one of the seven schools involved in the turf war.

This third video game in the series is based on the Xtreme Xecutor anime, called Ikki Tousen: Xross Impact (一騎当千 XROSS IMPACT Ikkitōsen Kurosu Inpakuto). It features a new character named Ato along with the return of Ukitsu as a playable character, and Koudai Chinkyu, Yojo Bashoku, Kyocho, and Chutatsu Shibai are added as playable characters. The game adds a "Super Arts" bar, tag-team battles and combos, and the addition of the alternate striker system. The gameplay was also revamped to include an aerial pursuit rave and a Finishing Screen.

Source: Wikipedia, "Battle Vixens", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118900.name: World Stadium
118900.description:
World Stadium (ワールドスタジアム) is a series of baseball arcade games that were released by Namco in the late 1980s and 1990s in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "World Stadium", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118903.name: Ajax
118903.description:
The game takes place in a fictional 2007 where the Earth has been conquered by alien invaders. The player combats the occupation forces using vehicles under operation code named 'A-Jax' created to liberate the Earth. Game play is divided into two scrolling sections with two different vehicles: the first being a vertical scrolling section with the helicopter and a Rail scrolling stage with the jet/space fighter. The game spans eight stages and extends are set to 30,000 and a second at 150,000 points.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ajax (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary

The game was also released under the name "Typhoon". This version was the same except that the stages were in a different order, starting with a fighter stage diving down upon a carrier, rather than a helicopter stage as in 'Ajax'. Typhoon was converted to a number of home formats.

118904.name: Jackass: The Game
118904.description:
Jackass: The Game is a video game based on the television series Jackass. The game was first shown at the 2006 E3 behind closed doors.

All of the Jackass cast (excluding Bam Margera) and crew provided their own voices and supply their likenesses for the game, according to Sidhe Interactive. Johnny Knoxville and other members of the Jackass team also provided stunt ideas to the developer based on unused stunts from the show. A trailer was released in June 2007 on the game's official website, along with the cover art.

Filling in as director of Jackass, your aim is to collect the best footage from up to 36 stunts throughout the game to create a new Jackass season for MTV. All stunts have a minimum requirement for content before MTV will approve an episode for broadcast. The new season requires seven episodes of Jackass footage.

Jackass offers two gameplay modes for players:
MTV Story Mode: The primary gameplay mode for Jackass: The Game, the narratives drives your progress through the game. By playing MTV Story Mode you can unlock new content within the game.
Episodes - Stunts are collected into groups called "Episodes". Episodes in the game are similar to the format and structure of the TV series, collecting a series of stunts which may or may not be related by a general theme. In each episode, the player is free to complete the stunts in any order.

Game Progression - Completing goals within a stunt attempt means collecting footage for an episode.

Source: Wikipedia, "Jackass: The Game", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118905.name: World Combat
118905.description:
World Combat (Warzaid in Europe) is a military themed first-person light gun rail shooter. The arcade game comes in two types of cabinets, one for four players and one for two players. The game possesses many similarities to Namco's Time Crisis series, not the least of which is the ability of players to take cover at will. Each player character comes equipped with a large, portable metal shield that can block incoming projectiles. Unlike the Time Crisis games, however, this shield is not activated by a foot pedal, but rather by pointing the gun outside the screen (like many classic first-person rail shooters, shooting off-screen also reloads the player's weapon). The game also features a mechanic similar to Time Crisis's "Crisis Sighting," where most enemy projectiles miss the player harmlessly, but those that are an immediate threat slow down and are much larger than normal, giving the player a small window to react.

Source: Wikipedia, "Warzaid", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118906.name: Jackie Chan Adventures
118906.description:
The Jackie Chan Adventures video game is based upon the Jackie Chan Adventures cartoon. Developed by Atomic Planet and published by Sony, it was released for PlayStation 2 on October 1, 2004 in Europe. It was compatible with the Eyetoy. Jackie, Jade, Uncle, Valmont and Shendu were voiced by their original actors.

The story is a mix of Seasons 1 and 2 of Jackie Chan Adventures and follows The Demon Sorcerers, led by Shendu, the demon of fire. The eight demons were banished to the Demon Netherworld by eight Chinese immortals using the magic of the Pan Ku Box. In present times, the Dark Hand, led by Valmont, are using the Pan Ku Box to unleash the demons upon the world. However, Jackie Chan, his niece Jade Chan, and their Uncle are willing to stop the evil demons from returning to the planet. The heroes, also known as the J Team, search for the magical 12 Talismans as well. Can our heroes save the world, or will the Dark Hand, Shendu and the Demon Sorcerers prevail?

Source: Wikipedia, "Jackie Chan Adventures (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118907.name: Wave Shark
118907.description:
User Summary

Wave Shark is a single player jet ski racing game from Konami. Race and jump against time.

118908.name: WEC Le Mans 24
118908.description:
WEC Le Mans, is a sim racing arcade game released in November 1986 by Konami. It was the first video game to depict the 24 Hours of Le Mans. The Lap of Le Mans is split up into 3 sections, as you pass through each of the 3 sections, the time of day changes from day to dusk, dusk to night, and night to dawn.

Source: Wikipedia, "WEC Le Mans", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118909.name: Winning Spike
118909.description:
User Summary

Winning Spike is a volleyball game from Konami. Follows standard play, rules and head to head competition.

118910.name: James Bond 007: From Russia with Love
118910.description:
007: From Russia with Love is a video game featuring Ian Fleming's secret agent, James Bond, based on the 1957 novel and the 1963 film of the same name. The game follows the storyline of the book and film, albeit adding in new scenes to make the game more action-oriented, as well as changing the affiliation of the main villains. Additionally, it features many elements of earlier Bond films to recreate the feel of the era such as the jet pack from Thunderball (1965) and the Aston Martin DB5 that debuted in Goldfinger (1964).

From Russia with Love is the first title developed by Electronic Arts Redwood Shores to use an integrated game engine for the 3rd person action and driving segments. It was a new engine that was not based on any of the technology used for previous titles in the series but the result was similar to Id Tech 3.

The game was penned by Bond veteran Bruce Feirstein who previously worked on the film scripts for GoldenEye, Tomorrow Never Dies, and The World Is Not Enough, in addition to the script for the 2004 video game, Everything or Nothing.

The game's soundtrack was composed by Christopher Lennertz. Additionally, Vic Flick, best known for playing the original guitar riff in The James Bond Theme announced that he contributed to Lennertz's score.

Unlike in the 2004 game, Everything or Nothing, From Russia with Love features a third-person multiplayer deathmatch mode, however it lacks a cooperative feature that was present in Everything or Nothing.

One of the most obvious changes to the story for the video game is the absence of the villainous organization SPECTRE, who played a vital role in the film. Due to legal issues that have plagued the James Bond series of films since 1963, the organization was renamed as OCTOPUS and appears to lack a central leader in the same vein as Ernst Stavro Blofeld. The SPECTRE name was tied up in a long-running dispute over the film rights to Thunderball, between United Artists/MGM and the now-deceased writer Kevin McClory.

The game begins with a standard pre-title sequence in which Elizabeth Stark, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom's daughter, is kidnapped by OCTOPUS while attending a party. Fortunately, Bond was assigned to attend the party for just such an event, and he defeats OCTOPUS and rescues Stark.

Similar to the film, OCTOPUS has conceived a plan to embarrass British secret service agent 007 for the death of Dr. Julius No from the film Dr. No, in which No was an agent of SPECTRE. The plan involves the theft of a Soviet encoding machine known as the Lektor with the help of a defecting Soviet agent, Tatiana Romanova. Romanova, however, is being used by OCTOPUS to lure James Bond into a trap; their ultimate goal is to let him obtain the Lektor and then ambush him for it, killing him in humiliating fashion as well. Romanova is sent by Rosa Klebb, an agent of the KGB (in both the novel and film, an agent of SMERSH) who has secretly defected to OCTOPUS. Her immediate subordinate, Donald "Red" Grant, protects Bond through the first half of the game and attacks him in the second. The game ends with a final assault on OCTOPUS headquarters.

New characters:
Miss Elizabeth Stark: Stark is the daughter of the British Prime Minister, whom Bond rescues in the pre-title sequence.
Eva Adara: The driver and henchwoman of Red Grant. She is both a driver and pilot. She is ultimately killed in the level "Octopus Base" where she attacks Bond with a parked fighter jet. When it is damaged to the point where it is about to be destroyed, she flies down the underground runway at Bond who is using a jet pack. Bond easily avoids her plane which then smashes into the closed hangar doors at the end of the tunnel. Her role in the game was, however, minor.

Source: Wikipedia, "James Bond 007: From Russia with Love", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118911.name: Wizz Quiz
118911.description:
User Summary

Wizz Quiz is a trivia game from Konami in the mid '80s. Answer questions to continue play

118912.name: Tactician
118912.description:
User Summary

In Tactician you fly your spaceship accross the bottom of the screen and shoot enemies that fly down at you. Try to get the high score.

118913.name: Jet Li: Rise to Honor
118913.description:
Jet Li: Rise to Honor features the likeness, voice acting and motion capture work of martial arts actor Jet Li, and features martial arts choreography by Corey Yuen.

Rise to Honor features a cinematic presentation designed to mimic an action film, with no loading screens and sections of the game split up into "scenes". A DVD-like chapter selection menu allows the player to go back to any past scenes once they have been cleared previously.

Played from a third-person perspective, the majority of the game is a beat 'em up, with the player using the right analog stick to direct blows at enemies. The game also features a number of levels where the player uses firearms with unlimited ammunition. During levels, the player constantly builds up a store of adrenaline, which the player can unleash to perform powerful hand to hand combat strikes. An alternative is, when using firearms, the player initiates a temporary slow motion bullet time mode similar to the video game Max Payne.

Source: Wikipedia, "Jet Li: Rise to Honor", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118914.name: Taisen Puzzledama
118914.description:
Taisen Puzzle-Dama (対戦ぱずるだま, lit. "Puzzle-Sphere War) is a puzzle series developed by Konami.

Source: Wikipedia, "Taisen Puzzle-Dama", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118915.name: Taisen Tokkaedama
118915.description:
User Summary

Taisen Tokkaedama is a bubble drop game. Play head to head, match up colored bubbles to drop them on your opponent.

118916.name: Teraburst
118916.description:
The game is set in 2017. An invasion of UFOs has appeared and started to invade Earth. You are charged to blast the aliens back into outer space with a hand-held, recoiling machine gun, homing missiles and Napalm bombs. The game progresses through four stages of aliens.

Source: Wikipedia, "Teraburst", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118917.name: Kamen Rider: Climax Heroes
118917.description:
Kamen Rider: Climax Heroes (仮面ライダー クライマックスヒーローズ Kamen Raidā Kuraimakkusu Hīrōzu, Masked Rider: Climax Heroes) features the protagonists of the Heisei superhero Kamen Rider Series. It is the first Kamen Rider fighting game to be released onto the PlayStation 2 since Kamen Rider Kabuto. The game was released as part of the 10th anniversary of the Kamen Rider Series by Toei, TV Asahi, Ishimori Productions, and Bandai. The game spawned several updates for the Wii and PlayStation Portable consoles as well as an American version for the Wii based on Kamen Rider: Dragon Knight.

Combat in the game operates on a basic three-button system, encompassing Weak Attack, Strong Attack, and Special Attacks (such as the various Rider Kicks). In addition to this, each Rider has the ability to perform a Form Change once the Rider Gauge at the bottom of the screen fills, whether by dealing or receiving damage or by charging the meter. Form Change can be used as a counter or to extend combos. A number of Riders also have the ability to summon Strikers, such as Ryuki's Contract Monster Dragredder or Den-O's DenLiner. Also, each Rider has a unique finisher called Rider Finale. This attack can only be activated when the Rider Gauge is full and press the R2 button.

In Decade Mode, the player follows Tsukasa Kadoya's journey through the nine Heisei Kamen Rider worlds as Kamen Rider Decade, fighting the other Riders and attempting to prevent the destruction of the worlds. Decade Mode differs from standard gameplay in that Decade's Form Change and Special Attacks are customizable with KamenRide Cards and Final FormRide Cards earned as the player progresses. The missions in the mode are divided by three levels, with the easiest missions can be played in Level 1 while the hardest can be found in Level 3. Level 2 and 3 can be unlocked as the player progress in Level 1.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kamen Rider: Climax Heroes", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118918.name: Thunder Cross
118918.description:
User Summary

Thunder Cross is a scrolling shoot'em up from Konami. Collect different power ups and bombs to shoot and destroy enemies. Fight bosses to get to future levels.

118919.name: Thunder Cross II
118919.description:
User Summary

Thunder Cross II is a sequel to the 1988 Thunder Cross. Collect powerups and bombs to fight new and tougher enemies and bosses.

118920.name: Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzledama
118920.description:
Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzle-Dama (ときめきメモリアル対戦ぱずるだま) is a Tokimeki Memorial themed Taisen Puzzle-Dama spin-off game. It is followed by its sequel Tokimeki Memorial 2 Puzzle-Dama. It was recently released in Japan on the PlayStation Store on January 13, 2010.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzledama", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118921.name: Kamen Rider 555
118921.description:
Kamen Rider 555 (仮面ライダー555（ファイズ） Kamen Raidā Faizu, Kamen Rider Faiz, Masked Rider Φ's, Phi's, or Faiz) is based on a Japanese tokusatsu television series. The catchphrase for the series is "Racing Instinct."

The video game is a fighting game which featured many of the characters from the TV series. There were several modes of gameplay for either a single play and two players. It was released only in Japan near the end of the TV series.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kamen Rider 555", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118922.name: Tokimeki Memorial 2 Puzzle-Dama
118922.description:
Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzle-Dama (ときめきメモリアル対戦ぱずるだま?) is a Tokimeki Memorial themed Taisen Puzzle-Dama spin-off game. It is followed by its sequel Tokimeki Memorial 2 Puzzle-Dama. It was recently released in Japan on the PlayStation Store on January 13, 2010.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tokimeki Memorial Taisen Puzzledama", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118923.name: Total Vice
118923.description:
User Summary

Total Vice is a two person light gun shooter. Use your gun to shoot down enemies and try to take down crime boss.

118924.name: Kamen Rider Blade
118924.description:
Kamen Rider Blade (仮面ライダー剣（ブレイド） Kamen Raidā Bureido?, Masked Rider ♠ (Blade)), is based on a Japanese tokusatsu superhero television series. The television show was the fourteenth installment in the Kamen Rider Series. It aired on TV Asahi from January 25, 2004 to January 23, 2005. It is a joint collaboration between Ishimori Productions and Toei.

The video game based on the series was produced by Bandai for the PlayStation 2. It is an action game that featured many of the characters from the TV series. It was released only in Japan near the end of the TV series on December 9, 2004.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kamen Rider Blade", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118925.name: Labyrinth Runner
118925.description:
User Summary

In Labyrinth Runner you play a warrior fighting your way through multiple types of creatures. Fight them and work your way through the maze.

118926.name: Kamen Rider Hibiki
118926.description:
This game is based on Kamen Rider Hibiki (仮面ライダー響鬼（ヒビキ） Kamen Raidā Hibiki, Masked Rider Hibiki), a Japanese tokusatsu superhero television series. The television show is the fifteenth installment in the popular Kamen Rider Series of tokusatsu programs. It is a joint collaboration between Ishimori Productions and Toei. Kamen Rider Hibiki first aired on January 30, 2005 and aired its final episode on January 22, 2006. This series is noted for introducing new themes and styles yet unseen in other shows. The catchphrase for the series is "To us, there are heroes."

The video game Kamen Rider Hibiki (仮面ライダー響鬼 Kamen Raidā Hibiki) featured a unique cross compatibility with the Taiko no Tatsujin Tatacon controller, where the taiko-like controller could be used in the rhythm game-like sections of Hibiki. It was also released alongside a special edition of the Taiko no Tatsujin series which included the theme songs of the Kamen Rider Hibiki TV show ("Kagayaki" and "Shōnen yo"). A release for the Nintendo GameCube was planned, but ultimately scrapped.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kamen Rider Hibiki", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118927.name: Twin Bee '91
118927.description:
User Summary

Twin Bee '91 is the sequel to Twin Bee. Fly as the heroic anime character. Shoot down objects and collect special powerups. Fight bosses to continue on.

118928.name: Bei bao ke zi you xing: 60 fen zhong you shi jie

boardgameversion.149922: Da Fu Weng Chinese first edition

118928.description:
The title of this game roughly translates to "Backpackers' free travels - 60 minutes to travel around the world". The goal is to be the first player to reach 40 points through traveling to various famous tourist sights around the world.

The game has two game boards; one working board and one traveling board. Each player starts in his/her personal corner of the working board. The players take turns rolling two dice and moving around the board accordingly. A player landing on a personal working field gains experience. A player landing on another players working field triggers a bank payment to that payment, depending on that player's experience for that particular field. There are also travel fields on which a player collects a bus, train or flight ticket. A player moving on or over his/her personal starting space gets some money and another travel ticket (up to a maximum of five that can be held in the hand.). Additionally, s/he can decide to go traveling by moving his/her pawn to the traveling board. A player who is on the traveling board starts his/her turn by paying 500 Dollars, then rolling the dice and moving on the traveling board towards any of four tourist attractions that have been randomly marked. After doing the move determined by the dice, the player can use a ticket to influence his/her movement, as stated on the ticket (however, using the ticket costs dearly, too). If a marked tourist destination is reached, the player scores points. If at the beginning of a turn a player cannot afford further travel, s/he moves back to the working board, trying to raise more money.

When a player has reached a sum of 40 points, the game ends and that player is declared the winner.

118929.name: Kamen Rider Kabuto
118929.description:
This game is based on Kamen Rider Kabuto (仮面ライダーカブト Kamen Raidā Kabuto?, Masked Rider Kabuto), a Japanese tokusatsu superhero television series. This tv show is the sixteenth installment in the popular Kamen Rider Series of tokusatsu programs. It is a joint collaboration between Ishimori Productions and Toei.

The video game based on the series was produced by Bandai for the PlayStation 2, under the name Kamen Rider Kabuto. Released on November 30, 2006, it is a fighting game featuring all Riders seen in the show and movie, along with Hyper Gatack. The game features 5 different modes of play, ranging from a story mode to several multi-player modes.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kamen Rider Kabuto", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118930.name: Twin Bee Yahoo!
118930.description:
User Summary

Twin Bee '91 is the sequel to Twin Bee. Fly as the heroic anime character. Shoot down objects and drop bombs on enemies.

118931.name: Kao the Kangaroo Round 2
118931.description:
Kao the Kangaroo Round 2 is an action-adventure video game released in 2005 by Tate Interactive, and a sequel to Kao The Kangaroo. The game is in the same series as Kao Challengers.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kao the Kangaroo Round 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118932.name: Salamander 2
118932.description:
Salamander 2 (沙羅曼蛇2 Saramanda Tsū?) is a scrolling shooter arcade game developed by Konami in 1996. The game is a direct sequel to 1986's Salamander and is part of the long-running Gradius series. The game is notable as it is the first in the Gradius series to incorporate three-dimensional graphic elements into its base of 2D graphics. It retains all the characteristic elements of its predecessor; two-player simultaneous gameplay, similar enemy and bosses, and inclusion of vertically-scrolling levels.

Source: Wikipedia, "Salamander 2", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118933.description: Le Donjon de Naheulbeuk: Les Barbares, an expansion for the 2010 cooperative game Le Donjon de Naheulbeuk in which the players try to recover the last of Gladeulfeurha's statuettes, allows players to take on the roles of barbarians, explore new game areas, and experience new monsters and treasures.
118933.name: Le Donjon de Naheulbeuk: La marche Barbare

118934.name: Dico Déclic
118934.description:
Dico Déclic is 120 cards of pure pleasure in the format "mini tarot," whatever you are a novice or a pro of word games.

Making a Dico Déclic is to form one or more words using all his letters. More long a word is, the more points he earns at the end of the game.

At the end of each round, players secretly note the words found, (with the number of letter of the longest word count as triple), then they pass their cards to their left neighbor for the next round.

Once all players have played with the hands of all players, all of the words found are revealed. The players compare the different Dico Déclic and score the points.

n.b. This game is available only in French at this moment.

118935.name: Stars
118935.description:
"Once upon a time, the stars bickered for their place in the sky."

A very thinky abstract for 2 players.

On your turn, you take actions using a basic action point system -
1 point = Rotate one of your stars.
3 points = Move one of your stars one space.
2 points = Pulse with one of your stars, affecting any other stars lined up with your star's colored sides in various ways, based on the particular color lined up.

Every turn, you get more and more action points to use. Dim (disable) all your opponent's stars or push half of them off the board to win.

118936.name: Total Distortion
118936.description:
From the back of the box:

"ACHIEVE FAME AND FORTUNE - OR DIE TRYING!

You are an adventurous music video director! You've risked your life and fortune on a one-way trip to the hard-rockin' Distortion Dimension in search of fresh material for your music videos! You might become rich and famous... or you may die a horrible death.

Here's the situation: You have this incredible tower equipped with video production gear and everything you need for survival. You've spent all your money to transport the tower and yourself to an alien dimension. You can spend days with all of the hi-tech toys in your tower, but you'll never become a success & make it home again unless you step outside the safety of your tower and explore the far reaches of the deadly Distortion Dimension.

Grab your video camera and start shooting! But to get the best material, prepare to overcome guitar warriors, puzzles, traps, starvation, exhaustion and other deadly obstacles. Hob nob with supernatural rock stars and try to make it back to your tower in one piece. Create music videos with hard-won media treasures. Hop on the video phone and deal with earthbound TV producers. Sell you creations for millions and you;ll make it big!"

118937.name: Elite Forces: WWII Normandy
118937.description:
User Summary:

WWII Normandy is an FPS set during the para-trooping operations that began D-day.

118940.name: Struggle of Japanese missions to Tang China
118940.description:
This is historical board game based on missions from Japan to China (630-894 A.D.) - see Wikipedia page.

This game was born from a joke title. So Japanese pronunciation of missions to Tang China is "Kentoshi (遣唐使)" as same as Japanese title of Avalon hill's Gladiator (剣闘士).
Incidentally, its subtitle is "Do You See Jianzhen's Tears!?"

The players either control Japan or Silla (one of the Three Kingdoms in Korea). The game actions is resolved by random chits and dice roll.
Winner is determined by Victory Points: Japan gets points if the mission returns safe, Shilla gets Points if the mission is removed along the way.

First published in Japanese Simulator Magazine renewal #3.
Republished in Wargame Japanese history #19 in September 2013.

118941.name: Mots ancrés
118941.description:
The game combines a French game quiz with a general strategy board game.

The object of the game is to discover a word puzzle in order to reach the island and win the game.

There are letters on the sea. Before to start the game each player must choose a 6 letter word from the list provided in the rules of the game.
Each player must discover the mystery word of an opponent:
- He may ask questions about opponent's puzzle by docking the symbol 'safe' photo of the symbol box
- He may obtain a letter of this word as soon as he approaches a small island of the game board
- With the money he earns He may buy vowels or consonants of the word puzzle or even to invest in additional questions.

Holder of the puzzle can only answer YES or NO to all questions.

If any player find the word puzzle before the opponent and reach the main island wins the game.

118942.name: Schöner Wohnen
118942.description:
user summary

shortcut 03

This shortcut contains background information to buildings for Space Gothic. It includes small appartments up to big buildings like a bank office, bars and office building. The GM gets drawings of the complete building and information about the living/working NPCs it also has information about the security sytems etc.

118943.name: La Bête du Gévaudan
118943.description:
The game is inspired in "Scotland Yard".

The Beast of Gevaudan living in Lozère County in France hides and sometimes rises to attack. It appears from time to time and moves constantly via rivers, roads and highways with the help on special cards and her location is not always known. The others players try to find her.

The game is sponsored by the department of Lozère.

118944.name: Tunne iseennast
118944.description:
"Feel Yourself" in English

Trivia game for schools. The topics are: Oriental way of thinking, Western way of thinking, psychology, environment, society, creation etc.

The question is readed and the player who answers correctly scores a point. Winner is the player who gets 3 points first.

118946.name: Die Brücke
118946.description:
shortcut 04

(The bridge) is a solo adventure for Space Gothic with a duration about 3 hours. The adventure start with the hanging of the character and the (hopeless) chance of getting out of the situation. - The adventure ends with the death of the hero.

___
user summary

118947.name: Chopper Down
118947.description:
shortcut 05

Chopper Down is an adventure for up to 14 heroes and with a duration of about 5 hours. The heroes have to find a lost priest (in style of the movie "Black Hawk Down") The adventure can be played in two groups, pilots and soldiers.

___
user summary

118948.description:
Spirit (of Shibumi) is a 3-player ball-stacking game that can be played with a Shibumi set. It uses a '4x4' holes board and balls in 3 colours.

Each player has an allocated colour, and they take turns during the game (white -> black -> red).

On your turn, place one of your balls on an empty hole or platform so that no other FREE ball (no balls on top) of the SAME colour is on the same row or column of the same level^. If you can't, then you must pass.

If all players pass in a single round the game ends. The player with most balls on the board wins.

Ties are possible, but rare.

Notes from the designer

^- Note that there are 4 levels.

This is an attempt to capture the spirit of Shibumi, by creating a very simple 3-player-only game.

Rules for this game are included in the soft cover Shibumi Rule Book

2-PLAYER VARIANT

2 players. Each player randomly gets 15 balls from a pool of 10 white balls, 10 black balls and 10 red balls.

Play as usual. When no legal moves are available, the player with less balls remaining wins.
118948.name: Spirit of Shibumi

118949.name: Spindizzy
118949.description:
Spindizzy is a mind-boggling game for 3 players that can be played with the Shibumi game system. It uses the 4×4 board, 10 red, 10 black and 10 white balls.


Rules

The board is initially empty.

Players choose a colour and start with 10 balls each.

Then each player passes 3 balls of their supply to the left neighbour, and 2 balls to the right neighbour. From now on, at all times during the game the players keep their balls hidden.

A player is selected to be the "master" of the first turn.

In each turn – at the same time – players secretly pick one of their balls from their supply and hold it – hidden in the closed hand – towards the other players. When all players made their selection, the balls are revealed simultaneously.

Now the colour of the master player’s ball determines which player (remember, each player is assigned a colour) must play the ball in their hand first. A ball may be placed on any empty hole of the board or on any 2×2 platform. Then in clockwise direction the other two players also place their balls.

Whenever a small 5-ball pyramid is formed, the player whose colour represent the majority (or, if there is no clear majority, the player who owns the top ball) scores 1 point.

The last player of the current turn will then be the master player of the next turn.

End of the Game

When the last ball is played and the point is scored, the game ends. The player with the highest score wins the game. In the case where 2 players are tied, the third player wins.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-a...

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

118950.name: Mafia

2378.name: Copag - Cia. Paulista de Artes Gráficas

118950.description:
The Mafia has never been stronger: assaults, ambushes, and smuggling are happening throughtout the streets. But the police is not playing around! Infiltrated police officers will attempt to sabotage Mafia missions at all costs to show who's the real boss of the city

At the beggining of the game, players receive secret goals: mafia or police. The first ones should complete the missions, while te second ones should force them to fail (secretly). When 4 missions have suceeded or failed, the game ends.

During the whole game, 2 missions remain open at the table, and different characters are assigned to them.
Each mission has a number value, a color and a quanitity of cards necessary to complete it.
Players who are at the mission can contribute (or not) to it by secretly playing action cards at it.

All action cards may be used to contribute for missions or may be used as an action. There is a wide variety of actions, such as adding or removing a character from a mission, buying more cards, forcing a player to lose cards, block a player's turn, etc.. but remember:
In the underworld of MAFIA, you never know whom you can trust!

118951.name: Teleprompter: Cyphers of the Spiritual Hinterlands
118951.description:
